Award.AwardTitle: The Role of Water Vapor in Midlatitude Stormtracks and the Global Circulation
Award.AbstractNarration:
A recent study of the isentropic circulations by the principal investigator and his collaborators has shown that the poleward mass transport in the mid-latitudes is equally split between a "dry branch" in the upper troposphere, and a "moist branch", associated with a low level poleward flow of warm, moist subtropical air that ascends in the upper troposphere within the stormtracks.

This project will develop a new framework to better assess the relationship between precipitation and mid-latitude weather systems on both the local and global scales, and will evaluate how the global circulation is affected by different climatic conditions. It seeks a better understanding of (i) what controls the partitioning of the circulation between these dry and moist branches, (ii) how does this partitioning affect the energy and momentum transport by the circulation, (iii) what are the implications at the level of the individual storm, and (iv) how this might change in the future either as a result of natural climate variability or as a consequence of anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions.

The approach here is based on analyzing the zonal mean circulation averaged on either dry isentropes, i.e., surfaces of constant potential temperature, or moist isentropes, i.e., surfaces of constant equivalent potential temperature. The research includes theoretical development to assess the role of moist processes on the dynamics of mid-latitude weather systems, numerical simulations of baroclinic life-cycle and of the global atmosphere, and a comprehensive study of the current circulation based on reanalysis datasets. A set of diagnostic tools to assess the isentropic circulation in numerical models will also be developed and made available to the broader community.

Broader impacts of the proposed research are in the potential to improve our ability to predict how climate change can affect subtropical and mid-latitude weather, and modify the global distribution of rainfall. Different global climate models used by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) will be carefully evaluated and compared to reanalysis data. This should both indicate possible ways to improve these models, as well as increase our confidence in their ability to accurately simulate the climate system and the hydrological cycle.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The atmospheric circulation acts to redistribute energy, water and angular momentum from the equatorial regions to higher latitudes. In doing so, it keeps the tropics relatively fresh and warms up the polar regions. This also plays an important role in establishing the main regional weather patterns around the globe: the equatorial rainbands, the dry subtropics and the midlatitude stormtracks. 

This NSF-sponsored research project has been focused on the role of water vapor in the meridional mass transport. Recent findings had shown that the meridional mass transport increases by a factor two once the water vapor is taken into account. It has been well-known that the description of the meridional circulation depends crucially on the averaging method. For instance, when the flow is averaged in geometric (or Eulerian) coordinates, the atmosphere exhibits a well-known three cell structure - the Hadley cell in the tropics, the Ferrel cell in the midlatitudes and the polar cell. In contrast, when averaged on isentropic surfaces, it exhibits a single Equator-to-Pole overturning cell. This discrepancy can be explained by the fact that midlatitudes systems that transport heat are also transporting air masses, which is accounted for differently by the various averaging methods. In this context, changing the a coordinate system can be interpreted as changing the angle under which one looks at the atmospheric circulation, and thus as a way of gaining new insight of how air moves.

The first task performed under this grant was to develop a new mathematical framework to explain the impacts of a coordinate transformation on the description of the atmospheric circulation. The previous technique, know as the 'Transformed Eulerian Mean' was only applicable under limited conditions. The new framework - the Statistical Transformed Eulerian Mean (STEM)- is not only more accurate by can be applied to a much broader set of flows. In particular, it was used to demonstrated unambiguously that the water vapor transport by midlatitude eddies corresponds to an additional mass transport that accounts for about half of the meridional circulation.

The STEM technique was then systematically applied to look at the variability of the atmospheric circulation under various conditions, such as the annual cycle, internal variability and climate change. We were able to show that most climate models predict a reduction of the meridional mass transport as a result of global warming. As the atmosphere warms up, it can contains more water vapor and thus transport more latent heat per unit mass of air. As a consequence, a weaker mass transport is sufficient to balance the difference of insolation between the Equator and the Poles. 

This project has also lead to a new promising research direction. The isentropic averaging that has been commonly used to study the large-scale meridional circulation can be extended to study the vertical mass transport in convection. This offers a new method to investigate the overturning flow in the atmosphere. It is currently being investigate to analyze the circulation in hurricanes and other atmospheric flows.
